abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Technology Project for
            India had a highly satisfactory outcome. The goal was to
            facilitate the acquisition and development of technology by
            industrial firms in India. This was goal was met by strong
            leadership that helped to grow the Industrial Technology
            Development (ITD) program, by adding Technology Institutes
            (TI) and creating funding for new technology curriculum. The
            role of the World Bank helped to accelerate reforms, in
            order for the project to move forward. The results featured
            different components from the project, the Technical
            Development Fund (TDF) that had 400 firms were able to
            import technology. New TIs were created, and upgrades were
            made to previous facilities. Sponsored R&D (SPREAD)
            programs helped to control the borrowing for funding, all of
            which helped  the success of the project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Technology Project's
            objectives are to boost technology acquisition, development
            and commercialization in India. The project comprises three
            complementary components respectively aimed at: (a)
            financing technology innovation by small and medium
            enterprises through four venture capital schemes; and (b)
            strengthening the capacity of research and standards
            institutions to provide technology services to industry and
            promoting collaboration between industry and research
            institutions. The third component involves (c) the import by
            industry of technology and technical know-how through the
            Technical Development Fund, a fast-track procedure for
            promoting technology modernization. Technical assistance and
            studies would also support the first two components.
